questionListItems.title: Can the courts order the sale (as opposed to a transfer (other than by way of sale)) of my share of the matrimonial property to my ex-spouse without any CPF refund?

answer.body: Upon the sale of your share of the matrimonial property to your ex-spouse, the required CPF refund has to be first returned to your CPF account. The Court can then order the transfer or payment of the refunded CPF savings from your CPF account to your ex-spouse’s CPF account or to you in cash if it so decides.

topics.title: Other schemes
Division of CPF-related Assets in Matrimonial Proceedings

questionListItems.title: Do I need to make any CPF refunds if I sell my share of the property to my ex-spouse?

answer.body:
Yes, the full required CPF refunds will have to be made to your CPF account upon your part-share sale of the property to your ex-spouse. 

If you intend to transfer your share of the property to your ex-spouse with no or partial CPF refunds to be made to your account, you may wish to consider obtaining a court order for a transfer of property instead. Please note that the relevant requirements in Part 3A of the CPF Act will apply. 

For more details, you can refer to 'How much do I need to refund to my CPF account if I am either selling my whole property, transferring or selling my share of the property to another party?' or the next section on Transfer of Property.

topics.title: Other schemes
Division of CPF-related Assets in Matrimonial Proceedings

questionListItems.title: Can I transfer my share in the property to my ex-spouse?

answer.body:
Yes, you can do so if the Courts decide to make such an order. The amount of CPF refunds, who is required to make those refunds and at what point in time the refunds need to be made will depend on whether the court order provides for full, partial or no CPF refunds to your CPF account upon transfer of your share in the property to your ex-spouse. 

We set out the CPF refund details in the table below:

Transfer of property with full CPF refunds

Transfer of property with partial or no CPF refunds
(A) At point of transfer of property from you to your ex-spouse

Required amount to be refunded to your CPF account:

1)   Your CPF principal amount withdrawn for the property with accrued interest, and

2)   Your pledged amount if you are aged 55 years old and above and have pledged the property to make up your retirement sum

Required amount to be refunded to your CPF account:

Partial or zero amount as directed by the court order
(B) Upon subsequent disposal of property by your ex-spouse
Required amount to be refunded to your CPF account: N.A.

Required amount to be refunded to your ex-spouse’s CPF account:

1)      Your ex-spouse’s CPF principal amount withdrawn for the property with accrued interest, and

2)      Your ex-spouse’s pledged amount if they are aged 55 years old and above and has pledged the property to make up their retirement sum.

 

In addition:

3)      Portion of the required CPF refund not refunded to your CPF Account at the point of transfer of property;

4)      Interest that would have accrued on (3) as at the date of your ex-spouse’s subsequent disposal of the property, and

5)      Your pledged amount if you are aged 55 years old and above and have pledged the property to make up your retirement sum

topics.title: Other schemes
Division of CPF-related Assets in Matrimonial Proceedings

questionListItems.title: I did not use CPF savings for the matrimonial property but pledged the property to make up my retirement sum. Can the Court order a transfer of this property to my ex-spouse?

answer.body: Yes, the Court can still order the transfer of the property to your ex-spouse upon the refund of your pledged amount to your CPF account. The Court may also order for the transfer with a partial refund or without a refund. However, upon subsequent disposal of the property by your ex-spouse, they will have to refund the pledged amount to their CPF account (if it was not earlier refunded to your CPF account).

topics.title: Other schemes
Division of CPF-related Assets in Matrimonial Proceedings

questionListItems.title: Can I use my CPF savings to make the required CPF refunds to my ex-spouse upon the transfer of property?

answer.body:
Yes, you can use your Ordinary Account savings and cash to make the required CPF refund to your ex-spouse upon the transfer of the property. You can check the amount you can use from your home ownership dashboard.

Please note that for HDB flats, your CPF usage may be subject to the applicable housing withdrawal limits, which will be determined when we receive the detailed information regarding the transaction.

topics.title: Other schemes
Division of CPF-related Assets in Matrimonial Proceedings

questionListItems.title: Can I use my CPF savings to pay for the cash consideration to my ex-spouse upon the transfer of property?

answer.body: No, you cannot use your CPF savings for any cash consideration to your ex-spouse in a property transfer. You may, however, use your Ordinary Account savings to make the refunds to your ex-spouse’s CPF account upon the transfer of property.

topics.title: Other schemes
Division of CPF-related Assets in Matrimonial Proceedings

questionListItems.title: What should I do if the Court has instructed me to use the cash consideration provided by my ex-spouse to make the required CPF refund upon the transfer of property?

answer.body:
You should check if the cash consideration is sufficient to make the required refund to your CPF account upon the transfer of property. If the cash consideration is not enough to cover the required refund, you will need to make up the difference in cash, in a lump sum, upon the completion of the transfer of the property to your ex-spouse.

On the other hand, if the cash consideration is more than enough to cover the required refund, the Board will only collect the required refund amount to your CPF account. For example, the Court has instructed your ex-spouse to pay you a cash consideration of $60,000 and you are to use this sum to make your required CPF refund amount. As at the date of transfer, your required refund is $25,000. In this case, the Board will only accept $25,000 to your CPF account.

topics.title: Other schemes
Division of CPF-related Assets in Matrimonial Proceedings

questionListItems.title: What are the ex-spouse's (remaining party) obligations following the transfer of the property under matrimonial proceedings?

answer.body:
If the Court so orders, the ex-spouse (remaining party) has to refund a sum (amount as decided by the Court) to the member’s (outgoing party) CPF Account(s) upon transfer.

The Court may also order the transfer of property with no refunds to the member’s CPF Account. If that is the case, upon the subsequent sale/transfer or otherwise disposal of the property, the ex-spouse would be required to refund  to his own CPF Account(s), the CPF monies withdrawn (including the accrued interest) by him and the member for the purchase of the property, and any amount in respect of which the property has been pledged to make up his and the member’s retirement sums.

topics.title: Other schemes
Division of CPF-related Assets in Matrimonial Proceedings

questionListItems.title: The courts ordered my ex-spouse and I to make our CPF refunds from our respective share of sale proceeds. My share is insufficient. Can I waive the shortfall in refund?

answer.body:
No, full requisite CPF refunds must be made in accordance with CPF legislation upon the sale of the property in a divorce. If your (or your ex-spouse’s) respective share of sale proceeds are not enough to cover the required refunds to your CPF account, you will need to make up the shortfall in cash. 

If you and your ex-spouse are unable to proceed with the sale of the property, please seek legal advice on how your proprietary share in the matrimonial asset can be satisfied.

topics.title: Other schemes
Division of CPF-related Assets in Matrimonial Proceedings

questionListItems.title: Under the division of CPF savings in a divorce, which investments can be transferred? Which investments have to be liquidated for proceeds to be transferred? Who should I approach for transfer or liquidation of investments?

answer.body: Please refer to the step-by-step guide (PDF, 55KB) for the details on the sale or transfer of investments under CPF Investment Scheme - Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA) and CPF Investment Scheme - Special Account (CPFIS-SA).

topics.title: Other schemes
Division of CPF-related Assets in Matrimonial Proceedings

questionListItems.title: I am required to give some of my CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) investments to my ex-spouse as specified in the Court Order. What should I do after receiving the Court Order?

answer.body:
Please submit the court order(s) for the division of CPF assets via our online service using the following steps:

For Members:

Scan or click the QR code, login with your Singpass, and complete the form accordingly:

Alternatively, you may submit the court order(s) using the following steps:

  1. At CPF website, login with your Singpass for my cpf Online Services
  2. Click on "My Requests" > "Other CPF Matters" > "Submit Court Order for Division of Matrimonial Assets"
  3. Complete the form accordingly

For Business Partners and Legal Aid Bureau (LAB):

If your lawyer or LAB is submitting your court order(s), they may scan or click the QR code, login with their Singpass, and complete the form:

Alternatively, they may submit the court order(s) using the following steps:

  1. At CPF website, scroll to the bottom of the page and click on "Business partners"
  2. Under “Business Partners Portal”, click on “Log in"
  3. Log in with Singpass
  4. Click on "Submit Court Order for Division of Matrimonial Assets"
  5. Complete the form accordingly

You should also proceed to execute the transfer or liquidation of your investments in accordance with the court order. Please refer to the step-by-step guide (PDF, 54KB) for more details on how a transfer or sale of CPFIS investments is effected from you to your ex-spouse.

Note: If you, your ex-spouse or your lawyers cannot submit the court order(s) online, you may make an appointment at our CPF Bishan Service Centre via Appointment@CPF for our Customer Service Executive to assist you with the submission. Please bring a copy of your court orders along with your identification document.

CPF Bishan Service Centre
3 Bishan Place
#01-01
Singapore 579838
(near Bishan MRT Station)

topics.title: Other schemes
Division of CPF-related Assets in Matrimonial Proceedings

questionListItems.title: Why do I have to effect the transfer or sale of investments under the division of CPF savings in a divorce? What happens if I do not come forward to effect the transfer or sale of investments?

answer.body:
You are solely responsible for presenting the court order and completing the necessary forms at the relevant financial intermediaries to effect the transfer or sale of investments because the financial intermediaries require authorisation and instruction from the owner, i.e. you.

If you do not sign the transfer form, your ex-spouse may apply to the Court for the Registrar of Court to sign the transfer form on your behalf. Your ex-spouse will need to furnish the required information (eg, Divorce Petition number, both of your names, contact numbers, CPF account numbers, Investment Account numbers, names of agent banks, name of your investments, name of financial intermediaries, etc) to complete the transfer form.

If you do not sell the investments as ordered, and the investments are such that they cannot be sold without instruction being given personally by you (as required by the financial intermediaries), your ex-spouse may request for the Court Order to be varied to transfer your investments to them instead. As this depends on the nature of the investments, your ex-spouse should make the necessary enquiries with the financial intermediaries concerned before obtaining the appropriate order.

topics.title: Other schemes
Division of CPF-related Assets in Matrimonial Proceedings

questionListItems.title: Can the cash balance in my Investment Account be transferred under the division of CPF savings in a divorce?

answer.body: Cash balances in your Investment Account can be transferred but you have to initiate the transfer of cash balance from your Investment Account to your Ordinary Account first before CPF Board can transfer the balance to your ex-spouse's Ordinary Account.

topics.title: Other schemes
Division of CPF-related Assets in Matrimonial Proceedings

questionListItems.title: How can I submit an application to transfer CPF Investment Scheme investments sale proceeds in a divorce?

answer.body:
You will need to submit the following:

  1. The court order; and 
  2. An application to transfer your CPF Investment Scheme investment sale proceeds here.

topics.title: Other schemes
Division of CPF-related Assets in Matrimonial Proceedings

questionListItems.title: What are the criteria to be fulfilled by my ex-spouse before my investments can be transferred to them under the division of CPF savings in a divorce? What are the options if my ex-spouse cannot fulfill the criteria?

answer.body: Before your investments can be transferred to your ex-spouse, they must be a CPF member who is Singaporean or Singapore Permanent Resident (SPR) and 18 years old and above. If your ex-spouse is below 18 years old, they can consider requesting the Court to order your investments to be liquidated and the sale proceeds to be transferred to their CPF accounts.
